article.Heading: See improvement in sales for auto industry next fiscal: CRISIL
article.Summary: After the gradual recovery in some segments this fiscal, CRISIL Research expects more broad-based growth in domestic automobile sales volume in 2016-17 as consumer sentiment is expected to improve on the back of a pick-up in real income growth and lower cost of ownership
article.Body:
Below is the state of the auto industry by CRISIL Research

Improving sentiment, softening rates, and low fuel prices to propel growth

After the gradual recovery in some segments this fiscal, CRISIL Research expects more broad-based growth in domestic automobile sales volume in 2016-17 as consumer sentiment is expected to improve on the back of a pick-up in real income growth and lower cost of ownership. But revival in rural demand, critically dependent on a normal monsoon, remains a monitorable for growth in motorcycles, light commercial vehicles (LCVs) and tractors.

Commercial vehicle sales to accelerate in 2016-17

We expect commercial vehicles sales to grow 7-9% in 2016-17, a tad faster than an estimated 5-7% in 2015-16. As replacement demand stabilises in medium and heavy commercial vehicles, growth in the segment will moderate to mid-teens from over 20% growth in the past two years. By contrast, LCV sales will grow at 4-6%, after three years of decline, due to improvement in private consumption and financing.

Cars & utility vehicles demand growth to touch double digits in 2016-17

Sales of cars and utility vehicles (UVs) rebounded strongly in 2015-16 and growth is likely to improve to 11-13% next fiscal, led by faster economic growth and better consumer sentiment (driven by rising affordability and competitively priced launches) along with interest-rate cuts and payouts arising from the Seventh Pay Commission recommendations and the One Rank One Pension plan.

Two-wheeler sales to recover in 2016-17 on normal monsoon

Two-wheeler sales grew by a marginal 1.4 % in 2015-16 (April-January). Motorcycle sales fell 2.2 % as demand from the rural market, which accounts for nearly 45% of domestic motorcycles demand, declined because consecutive below-par monsoons lowered farm incomes.

CRISIL Research expects two-wheeler sales to rebound in 2016-17, growing by an estimated 10-12% on the back of higher farm incomes and continued preference for scooters. Sales volumes for motorcycles will recover, growing by 6-8%. Pay increases linked to the 7th Pay Commission recommendations will boost scooter sales.
